chapter.title: Sojourners of Righteousness
chapter.subtitle: גרי צדק - Gerei Tzedek
chapter.para: This is probably the hardest of the gerim to translate. The reason is that the Hebrew word tzedek doesn't have a word to translate to that encompasses its properties of truth, correctness, uprightness, and righteousness.

Sojourners of Righteousness are seekers of Torah in whatever form they find it. They strive to constantly know haShem better and clearer. They are always increasing and never decreasing in this pursuit. If they fail, they spiritually fall to the status of ger toshav: the ger that is resting in place.

The ger tzedek is the ultimate path that haShem desires for the goy. The ger tzedek was from the lowly source of a goy, but is now seeking the ultimate Source of his true existence: haShem. However, haShem does not require a goy to become a ger tzedek. haShem only requires that he keep the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach. The passive nature of the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach allows the goy(if he keeps the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach he is now a plain ben Noach) to do as he pleases so long as he does not transgress the seven. It appears to me that these are designed in such a way to restrict any damage to creation if the ben Noach does not desire to seek his Source: haShem. However, the stringincy of the laws most likely will incentivise the ben Noach to see the Source of the harsh judgements of the seven, should he transgress them. The initiation by haShem Elokim to give the harsh laws for bnei Noach is so that bnei Noach will be encouraged to seek the Source of the harsh judgements. This initiation by hashem Elokim is given through the teaching of His Torah, by the elders of his community, etc. This is called illah eltatah(the higher initiation). "Why does Elokim act so harshly toward me if I trangress? If I even steal a pruta's worth of someone else's, I am worthy of decapitation!" When the ben Noach starts to earnestly question why these judgements are so harsh and starts to seek their Source, the judgements are now sweatened, because he is now seeking the Wisdom of haShem. This is called illah teta'ah(the lower initiation). This is the beginning of the path of the ger tzedek. The fear of haShem is the beginning of Wisdom. This wisdom leads to the da'at. Da'at leads to a love of haShem. The love of haShem leads to doing positive commandments.
The ger tzedek may spiritually occilate out of this seeking and yearning and fall to a lesser status such as a ger toshav or goy.

sidebar.para: Note: Gerei Tzedek is often translated as converts, proselytes, or righteous strangers. Actually, gerei tzedek is a Hebrew construct and should be translated as sojourners of righteousness. It is hard ot translate tzedek into English and "righteousness" is probably the closest thing. In my opinion, a more proper definition of tzedek would be something like "proper path" or "proper way".

This, more proper translation, lends gerei tzedek to be sojourner who are in a process of walking a proper path and not necessarily at the goal of the path. Such a ger is a ger gamor, or complete ger. It appears to me, that this is an individual that comes before a beit din to be accepted as a ger tzedek proper.

chapter.para: We can deduce that a ger tzedek exists outside of acceptance ot a beit din because someone who does teshuvah is a tzaddik at that moment. Also, any ger who is truly seeking haShem, Torah, or attaching to his people for the sake of Heaven is a ger tzedek. This type ger tzedek is one inwardly and is subjective. There is another ger tzedek, a ger gamor or completed ger, that objectively goes before a beit din to be tried and accepted as a ger tzedek.

Going before a beit din and asking to be accepted as a ger tzedek is required by halacha to become part of klal Yisrael. Before this acceptance by a beit din, the ger tzedek cannot and should not expect others to accept him as a ger tzedek, particularly in a Jewish community. Some reasons for this, is because klal Yisrael has certain halachic obligations to the ger and at this time when there is no Yovel year, only the ger tzedek can be accepted and have those obligations met. It is a mizvah for klal Yisrael to love the ger and not taunt him. The ger should also love bnei Yisrael and not expect them to open their gates of the community to just anyone who comes off the street. That would be dangerous and unloving.
